paragraphs.text: Muslims in the news only when they're behind the gun.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: Ahmed Merabat was the first of the 12 innocents killed in Wednesday's targeted attack on the French satirical magazine, Charlie Hebdo
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The 42-year-old French Muslim policeman was executed on the sidewalk of Paris' 11th borough - the enclave where Charlie Hebdo's headquarters is located
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Merabat was shot, point-blank, by one of the three assassins, minutes before they broke into Charlie Hebdo's offices, and slaughtered the magazine's top editor and celebrated cartoonists
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The coverage of the "Paris shootings" centred almost exclusively on Stephane Charbonnier, Georges Wolinski, Jean Cabut and Bernard Verlhac - the prominent and unyieldingly provocative minds behind Charlie Hebdo
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The first victim, Ahmed Merabat, was purged from the headlines
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The political and representational ramifications that come with highlighting Merabat's victimhood cannot be ignored
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: First
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it complicates the broader narrative that rigidly caricatures Muslims as terrorists, outsiders and marginals
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And second, refutes the state-sponsored indictment of Muslims in France as perpetrators of subversion, instead of law-abiding citizens
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Muslim and French
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Apart from the obvious tragedy, the Charlie Hebdo killings manifest the baseline that Muslim identity is only relevant - and indeed newsworthy - when the subject is standing behind the gun. Not in front of it
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In most everywhere in the world, but especially France - the architect of modern Islamophobia
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Muslims comprise a considerable percentage of the French polity
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Islam is the nation's second biggest religion
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: figures place the Muslim population at 5 percent to 10 percent of France's 66 million citizens
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: Islam's size, and demographical rise, has spurred some of the most draconian policies against Muslims in modern times
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The headscarf ban in 2004, followed by illegalisation of the niqab, or face covering, in 2010, codified core Islamophobic ideas
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: This legislation also functioned as a firm and fervent declaration by the state that Muslim and French identities were at odds and irreconcilable
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The French laicite model provided the structural underpinnings to carry forward Islamophobic legislation
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But more nefariously, guise it under the banner of state-sponsored secularism
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Expectedly, the religious expression bans disparately impacted French Muslims
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In addition
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: they chilled bodily and verbal expressions of Muslim identity
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The state aim of compelling secularisation upon its Muslim citizenry was based upon the civilisational binary, and ultimatum, to choose between "Islam and the West", "Muslim lands or France"
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Despite this ultimatum handed down from the state, the overwhelming majority of French Muslims exercised their faith amid pervasive bigotry
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And simultaneously, embraced their national identities as Frenchmen and women
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Extreme voices from within the state, and French civil society, looked to the three terrorists as representatives of the nation's 3 to 6 million Frenchmen and women
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Collateral indictment of French Muslims, by politicians and media alike, infused with an already fervent culture of Islamophobia on the ground, will surely incite violent backlash against Muslims and Muslim communities in the country
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Although unimaginable before Wednesday, French Islamophobia stands to become far more severe and strident
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The conflation of the terrorist's acts with France's Muslim population, from the perspective of hatemongers, holds the latter vicariously liable
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This connection, that links three deviant actors with an entire faith and millions of disconnected citizens, will fuel rabid backlash against Muslims in France, and more than likely, claim additional victims
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Centring Muslim victims, instead of villains, would mitigate the backlash considerably
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In addition
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: focusing on the heroics of Merabat, instead of the evil of the three terrorists, asserts - and inserts - a competing narrative that France's Muslims are everyday citizens
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Citizens with jobs, families, and interpretations of Islam that condemn violence, and contradict the malignant caricature of the faith constructed by the state
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Ahmed Merabat was more than a victim
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: He was far more than merely a Muslim
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: He, in both life and especially in death, stands as an archetype for the overwhelming majority of French Muslims
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: A law-abiding citizen, Merabat harmonised his religious identity with the responsibilities of being a Frenchman
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: He was both French and Muslim
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: an existential integration eviscerated by the longstanding Islamophobic discourse in France, and ignored by the media firestorm following the attack
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Although the first victim of the attack, Ahmed Merabat's story was shot down from the news headlines
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And his name and face absent from the ongoing stream of reports and narratives emanating from Paris on Wednesday
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Inserting him into the story, and countering the barrage of vile Muslim representations with a rebuttal of victimhood and valour, will likely save lives in France
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Most importantly, retelling the story from the perspective of Ahmed Merabat will not only reveal that Muslim and French identity are reconcilable, but also resilient
paragraphs.label: assumption
